Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Patient ID: [REDACTED]
Date of procedure: [REDACTED]
Attending physician: Dr. H. Malik
Assistants: Interventional pulmonology fellow; anesthesia team; radiology technologist.

Pre-procedure diagnosis: 17 mm solid right lower lobe medial basal segment nodule in a patient with oligometastatic colorectal cancer.
Post-procedure diagnosis: Same.
Indication: Local control of a solitary pulmonary metastasis in the setting of controlled systemic disease.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with 8.5 mm endotracheal tube; ASA class III.

Procedures performed:
1. Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy with cone-beam CT.
2. Transbronchial radiofrequency ablation of right lower lobe nodule using cooled RFA catheter.

Procedure description: After induction and intubation, the navigation bronchoscope was guided to the medial basal segment. A pre-procedural cone-beam CT set was used for planning. A bronchoscopy-guided cooled RFA catheter was positioned in the center of the lesion via an extended working channel, with position confirmed by fluoroscopy and repeat cone-beam CT. Radiofrequency energy was delivered in a single 12-minute application using a cooled system to limit airway injury. Post-ablation cone-beam CT revealed a sharply marginated ablation zone surrounding the lesion with an estimated minimal margin of approximately 5 mm, without pleural disruption. Bronchoscopy showed mild mucosal erythema but no charring.

Estimated blood loss: <5 mL.
Complications: None immediate; no pneumothorax or pleural effusion.
Disposition: Extubated in the operating room and discharged home after 6 hours of observation, with oncology follow-up and CT at 3 months.
